channel.title: Quartz
channel.description: Quartz is a digitally native news outlet for the new global economy.

item.title: "The Interview" made $15 million online.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The controversial North Korean-themed comedy was streamed or purchased some 2 million times on platforms including YouTube—making about five times more in online sales than at movie theaters. The film is also now available on Apple’s iTunes platform, and bootleg DVD copies are reportedly going for more than $50 within the hermit kingdom.

item.title: Qualcomm agrees to settle in China.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US chipmaker, which licenses its technology patents to smartphone makers, said it would reach an agreement to end a 13-month investigation by Beijing authorities into its pricing strategies. The deal will likely involve a large fine as well as an alteration to how the company operates its highly profitable licensing structures (paywall).

item.title: Libyan rebels attack the country’s oil sector.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Militant group Libya Dawn destroyed 800,000 barrels of oil—equal to two days’ national output—after it hit oil storage tanks in Libya’s Es Sider port with a missile on Friday. Three oil tanks are still on fire; the news nudged global oil prices marginally higher.

item.title: Kiev passes austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Ukrainian legislators approved measures to simplify tax laws and raise import duties, as it tries to meet the conditions for a major bailout from the International Monetary Fund. The new legislation will attempt to lower taxes for small businesses while closing loopholes used by the country’s oligarchs (paywall).

item.title: Winston Churchill's family feared he would convert to Islam.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: His future sister-in-law advised him to curb his enthusiasm.

item.title: There’s an Airbnb for Airbnb.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Potential hosts can find somewhere to stay while renting out their apartments.

item.title: White high school dropouts have better prospects in the US than black college dropouts.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: Xiaomi is the world’s most valuable start-up.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese smartphone maker confirmed reports that it has raised $1.1 billion from a group of venture capital firms for a total valuation of $45 billion, surpassing Uber. The company is expected to use the money for international expansion in southeast Asia, India, and Brazil.

item.title: China blocks Gmail.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The world’s biggest email service has been difficult to access since June, but users could still use third-party email software like the iPhone’s Mail app to access Gmail—at least until this weekend, when Beijing closed the gap in its Great Firewall. The blockage makes it increasingly difficult for foreign businesses to operate on the mainland.

item.title: A twin blow to Russia’s economy.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The country’s GDP shrank by 0.5% in November from a year earlier, and the HSBC manufacturing purchasing managers’ index for December dropped to 48.9, from 51.7 in November, indicating a sharp contraction in manufacturing activity. The impact of low oil prices and Western sanctions are only expected to worsen in the coming year.

item.title: Greece braces for a disruptive election.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The ruling party's Stavros Dimas failed to secure enough parliamentary votes to become president, so a general election will be held on Jan. 25. The leftwing Syriza party—which opposes the terms of the EU-backed bailout—is expected to win the popular vote.

item.title: Palestine is asking the UN for statehood today.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The resolution being submitted to the UN security council will call on Israel to leave the occupied territories by the end of 2017. Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat says they are hoping the UN will "conclude the vote by tomorrow or the day after." The US will probably veto it—but that's all part of the Palestinians' plan.

item.title: South Korea offers its northern neighbor peace.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ryoo Kihl-jae, South Korea's reunification minister, said he wants to hold talks in January and draw up plans for the decades-long conflict to come to an end. Seoul may be betting that Pyongyang's recent tension with the US over the Sony Pictures hack may make it more receptive to an overture.

item.title: Liberia is seeing a sharp Ebola flare-up.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Dozens of new cases have been reported on the country's border with Sierra Leone. This is despite recent reports that Liberia has managed to control the spread of the virus, which has now killed over 7,600 people. In related news, US health regulators have approved—for emergency use only—a new Ebola test that can diagnose the virus within three hours.

item.title: ISIL has executed almost 1,900 people in Syria since the summer.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In the past six months, ISIL has executed 1,878 people, mainly civilians but also including 120 of its own members—many of them foreign fighters trying to return home—according to the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

item.title: There are limits to capitalizing on a papal visit.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Philippines' largest broadcaster has pulled a controversial t-shirt—with the text "No race. No religion. I embrace diversity"—it was selling on its website ahead of Pope Francis' Jan. 15 visit. It was that middle statement, on religion, that prompted the local archbishop to "urge our Catholic faithful not to patronize items with misleading posts and statements."

item.title: Al-Qaeda calls for "lone wolf" attacks on British airlines.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The latest issue of Inspire, the online magazine published by the terrorist group's Yemeni franchise, says such attacks are the "West's worst nightmare." The article's author, Sheikh Nasr al-Anisi, identifies two airlines in particular: British Airlines and easyJet.

item.title: Uber's day of reckoning in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The app-based car service was banned in India's capital after a passenger said she was raped. Today the company is presenting its case at a hearing of the local transport authority. It has also published fresh safety measures, including closer scrutiny of its drivers.

item.title: London's iconic guardsmen are being pulled back.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Queen's Royal Guards—instantly recognizable for their red coats and tall bear-skin hats—are being withdrawn from posts outside UK palaces due to fears they may be attacked by terrorist groups. Britain's intelligence services say an attack similar to the 2013 slaying of Lee Rigby is a possibility.

item.title: China's president wants his people to learn more Marxism.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Xi Jinping is calling for "ideological guidance" at China's universities, saying said they should do more to disseminate Marxist political theories. His comments are another indication the Chinese Community Party will not be pursuing political reforms any time soon.

item.title: Here comes Shack-onomics.
item.dc:creator: mbackmanqz
item.content:encoded: The boutique New York-based burger and milkshakes chain Shake Shack just filed the precursor to an initial public offering, and the document offers up all sorts of goodies, including details about its rapid growth, plans for international expansion, and marketing jargon—like "Shack-onomics" and "Same Shack Sales."

item.title: The verdict for a Putin rival has been unexpectedly expedited.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: A Russian court moved the announcement of its ruling in the case against opposition leader Alexei Navalny to Dec. 30, after thousands of his supporters pledged on Facebook to attend on the original date of Jan 15. Navalny is accused of stealing money from a cosmetics company, but the charges are widely seen as politically motivated.

item.title: Shake Shack filed for an IPO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Started in 2001, the American hamburger and milkshake chain now has 63 restaurants worldwide. It had $82.5 million in revenue last year and expects to raise $100 million on a $1 billion valuation.

item.title: Searchers find floating debris and bodies from AirAsia flight #8501.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/tonyfernandes/status/549840195579703296 https://twitter.com/BBCBreaking/status/549834159448162304 https://twitter.com/STcom/status/549841543192797187 Earlier in the day, ships from China and the US, as well as Chinese aircraft, began traveling to the Java Sea to join the search mission.

Indonesian officials estimate #QZ8501 search area depth as 25-30m; will deploy 11 divers http://t.co/vYTpnLN6Ph pic.twitter.com/g7wfhjuB6r

— BBC Breaking News (@BBCBreaking) December 30, 2014

BREAKING #AirAsia #QZ8501 Navy spokesman says crew on choppers had visuals of people on the sea surface, not far from debris. (1/2)

— The Straits Times (@STcom) December 30, 2014

My heart is filled with sadness for all the families involved in QZ 8501. On behalf of AirAsia my condolences ... http://t.co/OJGobL93cR

#AirAsia flight #QZ8501: Plane spots ‘shadow’ on seabed believed to be AirAsia jet: Indonesia search chief

— The Straits Times (@STcom) December 30, 2014

item.title: Delhi regulators try to change everything about Uber.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The banned on-demand car company must adhere to standard rules for taxis, including painting all cars white and using only licensed cab drivers. The ruling was hailed by the incumbent taxi industry; Uber complained that the regulations will not help drivers or passengers.

item.title: Japan forges ahead with Abenomics.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The ruling coalition approved a corporate tax cut that will bring down rates to 32.1% from 34.6% in April, and confirmed earlier promises to reduce corporate tax to below 30% in the next few years. Japan’s cabinet is expected to approve the measures early next month.

item.title: Evidence shows that LA police shot a young black man in the back.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A newly released postmortem confirmed that Ezell Ford was shot at close range by police in August. Officers argued Ford attacked them; Ford’s parents have filed a civil rights lawsuit saying officers were aware of his mental illnesses.

item.title: At least 22 species of animal went extinct this year.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: That’s more than double the estimated rate in 2013.

item.title: The European parliament is literally a maze.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The confusing headquarters has nearly made grown men cry (paywall).

item.title: China makes 23x more watches than Switzerland, but creates a fraction of the value.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz

item.title: A Russian anti-corruption blogger is convicted of fraud.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Alexei Navalny received a suspended jail sentence after a fraud prosecution that many decried as politically motivated. Navalny’s brother Oleg was also convicted of fraud and sentenced to three and a half years in prison.

item.title: An attempted coup may be underway in Gambia.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Searchers find floating debris and bodies from AirAsia flight #8501.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Indonesian military recovered more than 40 bodies in the Java Sea, just 10km (6.2 miles) from where the plane—which carried 162 people—was last seen on radar. The location of the crash site in relatively shallow water should aid in recovering the plane’s black box and determining the cause of the disaster.

item.title: Hyundai bets on Chinese growth.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The South Korean car maker said it would build two new factories in China and increase output at another, despite concerns over slowing growth. The company, including its Kia Motors affiliate, said it would focus on making small- to medium-sized cars specifically for the Chinese market.

item.title: Dubai's international airport dethrones London's Heathrow.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: With 68.9 million passengers so far this year, the UAE's airport has overtaken Heathrow, with 67.8 million, as the busiest hub for international traffic. (Atlanta, in the US, is the busiest airport overall.) The emirate recently budgeted $32 billion to expand its second airport, Al Maktoum, to handle 120 million passengers.

item.title: Petrobras could go into technical default today.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Distressed-debt fund Aurelius Capital is pushing for bondholders of Brazil's state-run oil company to issue a notice of default for $54 billion of its foreign-held debt, after it failed to publish third-quarter results promptly. The delay is due to an investigation into a bribery scandal that has rocked the company this year.

item.title: Oil prices shrug off the "Libya effect."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A barrel of Brent crude now goes for less than $57, a five-and-a-half-year low, despite fires so severe at Libya's el-Sidr oil port that the country has asked US firefighters to come in and offer a helping hand. A Libyan official said on Saturday that the country has lost 850,000 barrels due to the flames (paywall).

item.title: The Italian ferry death toll remains unclear.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ten people officially died onboard the Norman Atlantic ferry that caught fire on Sunday, but the real number may be in the dozens, according to some reports. Rescuers evacuated 427 people, but 499 were thought to be on the ship, and there may have been stowaways too. Two Albanians seamen were also killed during the salvage operation.

item.title: US home prices are climbing faster than expected.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The S&P/Case-Shiller home price index says your average American home sold for 0.76% more in October than in September—higher than the 0.4% Wall Street was expecting. Those increases are distributed a tad unevenly, however; prices in San Francisco jumped 0.8% month-over-month, and 9.1% year-over-year, against a national average of 4.5%.

item.title: The macadamia nuts lady is facing arrest.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A South Korean court has issued an arrest warrant for Cho Hyun-ah, the daughter of Korea Air's chairman, for delaying an aircraft's take-off because a flight attendant served her a snack of nuts in a bag instead of on a plate. An airline employee will also be detained for attempting a cover-up.

item.title: Alexei Navalny defies his house arrest and gets arrested.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Police estimate 1,500 people joined the protest in Moscow in support of the Russian anti-corruption blogger, of whom they arrested 100 (link in Russian). Navalny himself, who earlier in the day received a suspended sentence for alleged fraud, was among them, after tweeting a picture of himself on the way to the march.
